 ARGENTINA STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT NATIVE FORESTS AND PROTECTED AREAS PROJECT 1. NATIVE FORESTS AND PROTECTED AREAS A. Background 1.1 The area of land with woody vegetation in Argentina is estimated at about 64 million hectares (23 percent of the country), of which forested land is estimated at between 35 and 45 million hectares. The area of native forest with commercial potential is estimated at about 15 million hectares; it produces about 1.5 million m3 of wood per annum, equal to about 40 percent of the country's annual production. Preliminary studies of about 78 percent of the land area of Argentina show that about 10 percent is affected by water erosion and 9 percent by wind erosion. Overgrazing and the destruction of the perennial vegetative cover (including loss of native forests) are contributing factors. Desertification in parts of the Chaco is one of the more problematic results of this degradation trend. 1.2 Argentina has barely begun to address the issues raised by its potential for producing public goods and services from its native forests, except through the establishment and management of a system of protected areas. The country lacks an inventory of its native forests, an evaluation of environmental threats to them and their economic implications, and a solid research and information base on which to base analysis of policy options. Without such information and analysis, it is difficult to develop either realistic plans or political consensus on how best to manage these natural resources in the public interest. 1.3 For example, the Chaco ecoregion, with an area of about I million km2, is the second most extensive ecosystem in Latin America, and 46 percent of it is located in Argentina. Despite this, and in sharp contrast to the Amazon ecosystem, it has received relatively little attention and remains poorly researched despite the critical role this woodland ecosystem is believed to play in providing a habitat for many endangered species of plants and animals, preventing desertification over vast areas of Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and Bolivia, and protecting and regulating both the quantity and quality of an important part of the water supply to two of the Region's principal rivers: the Paraguay and the Parana. 1.4 Argentina falls just short of being ranked as one of the Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) Region's countries with extraordinary diversity in terms of natural ecosystems. Yet it does have a diverse set of ecosystems and a wide range of plants and
 - 2 - animals. It is believed that there are about 300 species of mammals, 980 species of birds, 250 species of reptiles, 140 species of amphibians, and 312 species of fresh-water fish in Argentina. Many of these species are considered to be endangered or threatened, due in part to the loss of native forests. 1.5 Many countries use national parks and other protected areas as a means of protecting flora and fauna. Argentina is no exception, and about 4.4 percent of the national territory (about 12.1 million hectares) is protected. Argentina's percentage of total protected area is about average ror a group of countries examined. Of the total area protected in Argentina, about 22 percent is in national parks and the remaining 78 percent is under provincial or other control. However, many of the provincial protected areas are truly "paper parks," with no active management or day-to-day presence of guards. 1.6 What is more important than designation of protected areas, however, is the mix of ecosystems represented and the level of management. For example, only 0.2 percent of the land area of the Pampa grasslands, 0.5 percent of the Chaco, 4.2 percent of the Interior Atlantic coastal forest, and 5.6 percent of the Yungus are represented in protected areas. In addition, a recent analysis of management effectiveness in Argentina's protected areas estimated that less than 21 percent of the area under protection is acceptably managed, 30 percent is under some form of management though insufficient, and almost 50 percent receives little or no management whatever. Most of the area falling into the latter two categories is under the jurisdiction of provincial or municipal authorities or private landholders. B. Priorities for Government Action 1.7 The challenge facing the Argentine government in the management and conservation of native forests and protected areas is to develop and to put in place, at both the federal and provincial levels, the institutional capacity, the information base, and the policy, legal, and regulatory regimes that would encourage decision makers in both the public and private sectors to strike an appropriate balance over time between the production of public and private goods and services in native forests and protected areas. Defining an appropriate role for the state is critical in the development and consideration of government options. 1.8 Native forests produce commercial products such as timber, charcoal, and nuts, but they also produce a range of non-commercial goods and services. Examples are: serving as sinks for carbon sequestration, a global externality; preventing soil erosion, buffering water flows, and protecting biodiversity and watersheds, which generate global, regional, and/or national externalities. The production of important public goods by native forests requires that they be treated in special ways by the state and society at large. 1.9 The policies that contribute most to the destruction of native forests are those that constrain growth of the Argentine economy. Macroeconomic instability in earlier decades, which led to low or negative economic growth rates, contributed to loss of native forests by: (a) lessening the alternative job opportunities for poor rural families and thereby increasing the attractiveness of subsistence agriculture in or close to native forested areas; (b) lessening the investment opportunities available to most commercial farmers and
 - 3 - thereby making attractive the farming of land which in a well-managed economy would be regarded as sub-marginal for agriculture and left under native forests; (c) fostering inflation, which boosted the demand for inflation hedges, and, thus, the demand for land as a long-term but illiquid hedge, and cattle as a short-term and very liquid hedge, these demands encouraged expansion of the crop and livestock frontiers at the expense of native forests; (d) making counterpart funds scarcer and thereby depriving protected areas and other native forests of effective protection; and (e) lowering the priority attached to the preservation of native forests at the national level because of very pressing macroeconomic concerns. In view of this, the general policy framework that is good for efficient economic growth in general, is also likely to be most supportive of conserving native forests and strengthening the protected areas system, particularly over the medium- and long-term. Consequently, maintaining and deepening the reform process now underway in Argentina is a high priority for conserving native forests and strengthening the protected areas system. 1.10 In addition to putting in place policies and regulations which foster overall efficient economic growth, the government faces many additional challenges in developing and implementing a comprehensive and effective strategy for conserving native forests and strengthening the protective areas system. One challenge is to realize the efficient growth potential of commercial forestry in Argentina while avoiding the negative externalities associated with the loss of native forests to logging and conversion to other uses. This requires, inter alia, that the future source of growth in the output of commercial forestry products shifts progressively toward plantations and away from native forests. In turn, this requires a rapid increase in both the productivity and output of plantations, but this growth should be efficient and, therefore, quite different from much that occurred in the past. It should be driven by improved access to better quality information, technology and incentives which reflect the full range of costs and benefits, both private and public. The Forestry Development Project, which is being implemented by the Secretariat of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food (SAPyA), and supported by a Bank loan (Ln. 3948-AR) of US$16.0 million, helps the government to provide appropriate public sector support to forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry. 1.11 While efficient economic growth and appropriate public sector support for forest plantations are necessary conditions for the conservation of Argentine native forests and protected areas over the medium- to long-term, they alone are not sufficient. In the short- to medium-term in particular, accelerated economic growth will place increased pressure on some native forests from commercial logging. This could be the result of more profitable logging opportunities due to stronger domestic demand for the logs which come from native forests, lower transport costs, more efficient ports, and a more productive and motivated labor force. The same forces that may drive commercial loggers to cut more trees in native forests could also lead to the clearing of selected native forests for alternative land uses such as cropping and ranching. While some of these activities would undoubtedly be efficient from an economy-wide perspective, much of it would probably not be, particularly in instances where substantial negative externalities would be involved and decisions to cut the native forests are based on a consideration of private costs and benefits only. Therefore, the government cannot depend exclusively on market forces to determine the use of resources in native forests because the presence of substantial
 externalities will lead the private sector, acting alone, to misallocate resources in too many instances. 1.12 A major challenge, therefore, is to find efficient and effective ways of preventing this misallocation of resources in native forests. One such way is to reform the policy, legal and regulatory framework. At a minimum, the policies and regulations that create incentives to destroy native forests in an inefficient manner should be identified and changed. In addition, an optimal policy, legal and regulatory framework would actually encourage decision makers, both public and private, to internalize in their decision making processes the full range of costs and benefits resulting from management decisions affecting native forests and protected areas. Identifying ways to prevent misallocation of resources in native forests as a result of deficiencies in the policy, legal and regulatory framework would require a substantial amount of effort. Since nearly all forests (apart from national parks) are under provincial jurisdiction and are privately owned, and since a high percentage of the policies and regulations are also at the provincial level, the federal government would have to use persuasion and incentives to bring about the desired changes. 1.13 Two kinds of policy instruments are available to effect the production of non- commercial forestry products on privately-owned land (most native forests in Argentina are privately owned): (a) market-based instruments, such as payments and taxes; and (b) "command and control" instruments, such as regulations and standards. In general, market-based instruments are to be preferred to "command and control" measures. More specifically, the guiding principle should be to pay for the production of public goods from the forest sector or, alternatively, to tax competing goods, with due regard to the net effect on the government budget and resource allocation within the rural economy. If the value of the public goods that would be generated from the proper management of privately owned native forests is substantial, there should be no objection, in principle, to the government paying to such private owners an appropriate price in the form of a conservation payment for these goods and/or services flowing to society, provided such payments are necessary to preserve the flow of such public goods and services. 1.14 Before attempting to implement any such payment schemes, however, research information is required on the magnitude and value of the non-commercial goods and services produced in different native forests, and how the production levels of such goods and services might be most efficiently increased or maintained, as appropriate. Research of this kind would, in most instances, be appropriately seen as a public good.' For example, research to identify critical watersheds and habitat, and on the merits of the various options for protecting such watersheds and habitat, produces public goods and services and justifies, in principle, public sector financing. Generating the research information necessary for reaching a political consensus on the value of such public goods and services, as well as designing effective and efficient payments schemes, is, therefore, a research priority for the managers of native forests in Argentina. I The term "public good" is used here to describe goods that produce substantial positive externalities.
 - 5 - 1.15 Federal payments to provinces for conservation as part of a national system for the management of native forests are likely to be among the few mechanisms the federal government will have for influencing provincial forest policies and regulations. Conservation payments should be given to a province only when its forestry policies and regulations meet minimum federal standards. Such federal controls are necessary because payments alone will be ineffective if other parts of the incentive system are incorrect. There may also be externalities not well internalized at the provincial level, but which are internalized at the federal level. Designing appropriate and effective federal/provincial roles and relationships in the management of native forests and protected areas is a major challenge in Argentina. 1.16 Another dimension of these native forest ecosystems is their ability to generate global externalities, in the form of globally unique biodiversity as well as reduction of greenhouse gas emissions through carbon sequestration. As the costs of capturing these global externalities, however, are largely additional to the costs that would be incurred for investments contributing to Argentina's sustainable development, they pose financial burdens which the country is ill-prepared to meet. In such circumstances, it may be appropriate to solicit financing from grant sources (such as the GEF), in support of high priority, cost-effective programs with identifiable global benefits. C. Major Public Sector Institutions Involved 1.17 The role of the state in the management and conservation of native forests and protected areas mapped out above would include: (a) adapting existing policies, laws and regulations to new requirements; (b) managing in an effective way the protected areas system; (c) generating and disseminating relevant information and data and making it available to interested parties directly or through extension activities; and (d) fostering relevant training at all levels. 1.18 To perform this role adequately, substantial improvement is required in the existing institutional capacity. The Argentine National Forestry Institute (IFONA), an autonomous agency under the institutional umbrella of the SAPyA, was responsible for overall management of the forest sector until late 1991, when it was dismantled.2 IFONA's functions were divided between the newly-created Directorate for Native Forests (DRFN) within the Secretariat of Natural Resources and Human Environment (SRNyAH), which was given responsibility for all aspects of native forests, and the SAPyA's Directorate for Forestry Production (DPF), which was given responsibility for forest plantations, timber processing industries, and agroforestry. The National Parks Administration (APN), a semi-autonomous agency within SRNyAH, has responsibility for protected areas at the federal level. 1.19 The 23 Argentinean provinces have different structures of government and administration. In the forest sector, however, while the names of the administrative units differ, the general institutional design is relatively simple. The focal point is a provincial Forestry Directorate (Direccion de Bosques) with responsibility for coordinating the 2 Decree 2284 of October. 31, 199 1.

Previous Bank Lending 1.20 This is the Bank's second free-standing forestry project in Argentina. Earlier, as part of the Agricultural Services and Institutional Development Project the Bank supported a small sub-component for forestry research (US$1.9 million), and more recently it approved the Forestry Development Project (Ln. 3948-AR), which focuses on forest plantations, timber processing industries and agroforestry and is being implemented by SAPyA. E. Lessons from General Bank Experience 1.21 The Bank has lent over US$2 billion for forestry components and free-standing forestry projects. The Forestry Policy Paper of 1978 re-directed Bank financing from an almost exclusive focus on industrial forestry, to a new generation of social and rural development, and environmental forestry projects. Sector work was stressed as the critical link between the policy statement and the lending program. Only one Implementation Completion Report (ICR), and no Project Audit Report (PAR), exists for the forestry sector in the Latin America and the Caribbean Region, Lessons learned and other conclusions are derived from Bank studies of sectoral experience. A 1991 Operations Evaluation Department (OED) study of the Bank's forestry experience concludes that the overall performance of this new generation of projects has been satisfactory.3 However, consolidation may be a problem given the long maturation period of such projects, especially of their institutional development objectives. The OED study indicates that the nature, structure and operational effectiveness of institutions are critical determinants of the impact of environmental forestry projects, and that this is likely to intensify in the 1990s as political pressure is exerted on environmental and forestry institutions to broaden their agendas to incorporate protection, management, biodiversity and conservation. 1.22 An analysis carried out by OED concludes that the development frontier for the forest sector in the 1990s is in institutional and human resources, as well as research and information systems for forest and other natural resources. Macroeconomic policies and the incentive structure, including the legal and regulatory context, are vital, especially for enhancing private sector conservation involvement. These lessons are also generally corroborated by the 1991 Board paper on Forestry and the 1994 Board paper on forestry project implementation. 1.23 The proposed project represents an appropriate set of public sector interventions aimed at improving the productivity of native forests while being sensitive to environmental issues in native forest and other ecologically fragile areas. It heeds lessons from Bank and non-Bank projects, in LAC as well as in Asia and Africa, that native forests and other wildlands are a resource capable of being managed for multiple outputs, 3 Forestry Development: A Review of Bank Experience, OED Report No. 9524, April 22, 1991.

A description of lessons learned and how the project was designed to take these lessons into account is given in Annex A. F. Bank Group Strategy 1.24 The Bank's country assistance objectives and strategy for dealing with native forests and the protected areas system have been defined through intensive mission contact since the start of 1992, leading to a Forestry Sector Review (Report No. 11833- AR, dated April 26, 1993), and continuing into the identification, preparation and appraisal of the proposed project. The solutions to the issues and problems that confront Argentine native forests and protected areas are consistent with the Bank's country assistance strategy and its forestry, environmental, and sector policies. Bank support for economy-wide policies and actions necessary, inter alia, for the realization of Argentina's commercial forestry potential is being pursued as part of the country dialogue and economic work program. 1.25 Regarding native forests and the protected areas system, it is proposed that the other policies and actions deemed appropriate be pursued under the proposed Native Forests and Protected Areas Project. The Bank can be of great assistance to the government in helping it to develop and to implement an appropriate state role in the conservation and management of native forests and the development and management of the protected areas system.
 2. THE PROJECT A. Origin and Concept 2.1 Because of the commercial products produced by native forests, and the positive externalities benefiting the domestic economy which they and protective areas produce, the Government gives high priority to their improved management and conservation, as evidenced by the establishment of SRNyAH, the ratification of the Biodiversity Convention, and the elaboration of a Biodiversity Strategy. The recently completed Forestry Sector Review (Report No. 11833-AR, dated April 26, 1993), and the follow-up discussions with Government, including those related to the preparation of the proposed project, have provided useful opportunities for exploring the strategic options open to government. The emerging strategy now envisages a role for the state in native forests and protected areas which would focus on: (a) the creation of a framework of policies, laws, regulations and norms which efficiently protects and enhances the flows of goods and services from native forests and protected areas, including, in particular, the flows of public goods and services; (b) the generation of information required for the appropriate management of native forests and protected areas, giving due weight to the production of both private and public goods and services; and (c) the maintenance under direct public sector management, or under some form of public sector-sanctioned management regime, of native forest areas with the potential to produce particularly valuable flows of public goods and services in a cost-effective manner. The proposed project would help the Government implement the public sector role outlined here in partnership with other members of the civil society. B. Project Objectives 2.2 The objectives of the project are to: (a) help SRNyAH prioritize its proposed actions dealing with native forests; (b) facilitate the development of an incentive and regulatory framework which would encourage decision makers, both public and private, to more fully internalize within their decision making processes the full range of social costs and benefits associated with their decisions and actions affecting native forests; (c) develop a plan for transforming APN into a world-class park management organization; and (d) increase the environmentally sustainable level of tourism in four national parks: Lanin, Nahuel Huapi, Los Alerces, and Los Glaciares. C. Project Description Project Components 2.3 To achieve these objectives the project would: (a) prepare draft legislation for reforming the policy and regulatory framework affecting native forests at both the federal and provincial levels; (b) carry out an inventory of native forests from which it would generate and disseminate information on the geographic distribution of native forests within Argentina; (c) based on the inventory and other analysis, identify the priority areas of native forests deserving of protection; (d) based on the findings of an applied research and studies program and other information, develop options from which the government
 - 9 - and the private sector might choose an appropriate response to different threats in these priority areas; (e) develop a plan for transforming APN into a world-class park management organization; (f) build additional infrastructure and improve management in four national parks (Lanin, Nahuel Huapi, Los Alerces, and Los Glaciares); and (g) establish a project implementation unit (PIU) which would assist DRFN and APN with project implementation. 2.4 The project would have three components: (a) generation and dissemination of research and information; (b) protected areas; and (c) project implementation. Generation and Dissemination of Research and Information Component (Baseline Costs US$13.4 million) 2.5 An information generation and dissemination component would support actions and investments aimed at generating information with a high public-good content concerning native forests and protected areas. It would have the following three sub- components: (a) reform of the policy, legal and regulatory framework affecting native forests; (b) a national inventory of native forests, and establishment and operation of a related database; and (c) applied research and studies to facilitate the improved management and conservation of native forests and protected areas. Further details on this component are given in the following paragraphs and in Annex B. 2.6 Policy, Legal and Regulatorv Reform (Baseline Costs US$0.9 million). SRNyAH is the agency assigned responsibility for managing the federal role in native forests. In discharging this responsibility, one of the principal instruments available to it is the policy, legal and regulatory framework which is in place at the federal level affecting the management of native forests. This framework has many weaknesses which must be addressed as the first step in any strategy to improve the management of native forests in Argentina. A detailed study would be completed of existing federal legislation and regulations affecting the use and conservation of native forests to identify the main obstacles to their better management, including obstacles to the internalization of environmental values in private and public decision-making. The study would be followed by workshops with representatives of the public and private sectors and non- governmental organizations (NGOs). The objectives of the workshops would be to obtain feedback on the results of the above study, to agree on a hierarchy of problems, and to prioritize obstacles to be removed. Draft legal documents would then be prepared, incorporating proposed changes in existing laws and regulations. 2.7 Because most laws and regulations affecting native forests are enforced by the provinces, a concurrent and similar effort would be launched at the provincial level with the objective of aligning proposed provincial legislative changes with those proposed at the federal level. During negotiations, agreement was reached that the TOR of all consultants would include the obligation that they carry out their work on the basis, inter alia, of the Bank's Operational Policy (OP) 4.36 on Forestry, and OP 4.04 on Natural Habitats, which are incorporated in the Project Implementation Manual (para. 3.1 (a)). The baseline cost of this sub-component would be US$0.9 million, and would include expenditures for consultants, technical assistance, training tours, and workshops.
 - 10- 2.8 National Inventory of Native Forests and Management of a Related Database (Baseline Costs US$7.5 million). For SRNyAH to establish priority geographical areas of native forests on which to focus its attention, it would require, at a minimum, certain critical information about the total stock of native forests as a basis for analysis and decision making. However, there has never been an inventory of native forests in Argentina and reliable knowledge on their extent, ownership, distribution and condition is lacking. There is also little information on the nature and importance of the threat being posed to biodiversity in these forests, and the dynamics of change in forest cover (deforestation and degradation). Some of the critical information that SRNyAH requires for analysis and decision making would be generated by the inventory sub-component. The objectives of the sub-component would be: (a) to complete an inventory of native forests, including their biodiversity in carefully selected areas; and (b) to develop and manage a related database so that SRNyAH would have the capacity to store, retrieve, analyze and publish reliable information related to its mandate governing native forests. 2.9 The first objective of the sub-component would be pursued by completing a two- phased inventory of native forests. Phase I (baseline costs US$1.9 million) would involve: (a) the purchase of two sets of computer-compatible tapes of satellite imagery for the entire area of Argentina, one at the beginning of the project, and the second toward the end; (b) the preparation from an analysis of the first set of these tapes of a basic ecosystem map for the entire country, which would be used, inter alia, to provide information on land use, the broad distribution and extent of the principal ecosystems in the country, including native forests and protected areas; and (c) the preparation from an analysis of the second set of these tapes of a basic ecosystem map for the entire country with emphasis on native forests and protected areas, which would form the foundation for monitoring changes in native forests, other ecosystems and protected areas. 2.10 Phase 2 (baseline costs US$4.2 million) of the inventory of native forests would first require that the approach and methodology for completing the inventory be agreed between SRNyAH and other interested parties so that a standardized and technically sound approach is adopted from the outset, one that would enable all data generated to be efficiently incorporated and processed in the database. Internationally recruited consultants (the lead consultant firm for both phases) would play a central role in this undertaking, as would a workshop to elicit stakeholder participation and foster consensus before the fieldwork is begun. Once the approach and methodology is agreed under Phase 2, and because Phase I would be proceeding in parallel, field work could begin once sufficient progress has been made under Phase 1. 2.11 Phase 2 would involve systematic field sampling, or ground truthing, to verify spectral signatures of different tree species on satellite images, to obtain more detailed information on soils, slope, ownership, recent land use history, and habitat disturbance. Biodiversity inventories would be carried out in carefully selected priority areas within the five principal forest formations, namely, the Yungas, the Paranaense, the Chaco, the Espinal and Sub-Antarctic Forests. These would be used to determine biodiversity indices in these formations, assess species endemism, refine ecotype boundaries, measure species dominance, define species hierarchies, describe habitat structures, assess degree of threat, identify areas in need of protection, and monitor the dynamics of change over time.
 - 11 - 2.12 In addition to generating raw data by carrying out the national inventory of native forests, it is necessary that SRNyAH put in place a database system for processing this data and transforming it into information that can be readily accessed by users (baseline costs US$1.4 million). In addition to inputting data generated by the inventory, SRNyAH would input into the database existing pertinent information available anywhere in Argentina, including that available in the different parts of SRNyAH, SAPyA, the German Technical Assistance Agency (GTZ), and the provinces. To some extent, at least, this database would have to be custom designed to meet these requirements of SRNyAH, and to help it fulfill its mandate as the lead federal agency dealing with native forests. The present small statistics unit (3 persons) in DRFN would be transformed into a Database Management Unit (DBMU) with responsibility for developing and managing this SRNyAH database. This would require a substantial effort in institutional strengthening, including training, so that this new DBMU would have the capacity to discharge its responsibilities. The management of natural resources and the strengthening of institutions are two critical, interdependent ways in which governments can ensure the sustainability of economic development. The adoption and financing of an environmentally sound resource management strategy is unlikely to succeed without the managerial, technical and operational support of efficient institutions. Lessons from Bankwide Experience 2. OED has evaluated several hundred completed Bank projects with forestry/environment and institutional objectives and has derived broad-based recommendations for future lending. OED has concluded that natural resource advice should be a central element in the design of sustainable country strategies and development programs, and the Bank should help countries incorporate environmental concerns into macroeconomic planning. The basis for this advice should be sector work which stresses sustainable development as a matter of economic efficiency, identifies a set of policy options, defines informational needs for improved planning and policymaking, and provides a strong operational foundation for Bank lending. The recent Forestry Sector Review for Argentina (Report No. 11833-AR, dated April 26, 1993) meets these requirements. It has been discussed with Government and is a key reference for the Government's evolving forestry/natural resource conservation strategy. 3. The Bank should assist governments to assess the trade-offs, if any, between growth, equity, and sustainability, an effort which requires strong technical criteria based on research, natural resource inventories, and information and database development to establish the benefits of resource conservation and to design appropriate growth-related or environmental incentives. OED cites the importance of the incentive structure in natural resource strategies; personal benefits must be evident, understandable, and fairly imminent. A LAC study on deforestation in Costa Rica (1992) showed that forest protection for example, will rarely be a competitive use of forest resources for private agents unless they are paid for potential income foregone, a principle which research will determine may well apply to a variety of habitat. The idea of compensation is also raised in OED's comprehensive Forestry Development: A Review of Bank Experience (1991). The participation of local people in designating protected areas may require compensating them, while revenue raising schemes for their benefit might increase their acceptance and decrease the enforcement burden.

OED analysis shows that institutional weaknesses have seriously undermined the more complex collaborative arrangements usually needed in environmental forestry projects due to their multi-purpose nature. However, few of the many Bank-financed institution-strengthening components have had lasting effects, a major concern given the increasing complexity of projects and the diversity of the demands being placed on institutions. OED concludes that the nature, structure and operational effectiveness of institutions are a critical determinant of the impact of environmental forestry projects, and that this is likely to intensify in the 1990s as political pressure is exerted on environmental and forestry institutions to broaden their agendas to incorporate protection, management, biodiversity and conservation. 5. Several OED analyses of Bank technical assistance for institution-building conclude that success entails: a high level of commitment and mutual interest on the part of borrower and donor; project design which capitalizes on existing opportunities and forms part of a well-defined, economic and sector work (ESW) based institutional development plan; concentrating on technical, managerial and administrative systems development; attention to legal and regulatory issues governing both the relevant natural resource subsectors and the powers, functions and responsibilities of the institutions themselves; and decentralization of planning, policy and implementation to state and local authorities, limiting central government responsibilities to normative, enforcement and administrative functions. 6. Lessons from specific projects corroborate the above. The Brazil National Environment Project (Ln. 3173-BR) is confirming the need for: a thorough institutional analysis early on; greater attention to institutional capacity building lest undue reliance has to be placed on the project coordinating unit and technical experts, thus reducing the institutional benefits of the project; more strategically oriented, simple project design, and rational sequencing of project activities. The recent restructuring of this project stresses new, decentralized approaches to environmental management, including the use of market- based incentives. Equally germane are the Rond6nia and Mato Grosso Natural Resource Management Projects (Ln. 3444-BR and 3492-BR) currently being implemented. Both projects contain institution strengthening, and decentralization of environmental policy to the municipalities. Experience points to the importance of strong environmental agencies at the state level and of timely consultation with a broad variety of entities, especially on zoning issues. Institutional development should also include analysis of the legal framework and agencies' internal managerial and organizational capacities. Lessons of Native Forest Management in LAC 7. While the technical feasibility of improved native forest management in LAC has been demonstrated, important constraints

Applied Research and Studies in the Chaco Region - Rationale and Objectives. The Chaco region has the second largest vegetation type (after the Amazon) found in Latin America, and occupies over one million km2 in four countries (Argentina has 46 percent
 -44- Annex B of the total area, Paraguay 32 percent, Bolivia 15 percent, and Brazil 7 percent). The Chaco vegetation type is by far the largest forest/vegetation type in Argentina, where it covers some 500,000 km2 of the total surface area of the country. Although the Chaco region appears flat and uniform, it contains marshlands, palm savanna, several varieties of grasslands, brushlands and thorn forests at higher elevations. The main forest type of the Chaco region is the Parque Chaqueno, which is part of the Gran Chaco that extends from Argentina to Bolivia and is characterized by low rainfall (600-1,000 mm per year) and low deciduous forests, consisting mainly of the species Quebracho colorado, Quebracho blanco, and Lapacho negro. Stocking and annual increment are both low in the Chaco region, averaging about 100 m3 per ha and 1 m3 per ha per year, respectively. At lower elevations, the soils are silty mud with a clay hardpan that inhibits percolation. These soils are rich in minerals, calcium, phosphorous and potassium, but low in organic matter. 14. The Chaco region's vegetation has been severely degraded over years of mismanagement, especially overgrazing and unplanned tree harvesting. This has led to desertification, soil erosion, and decreased infiltration, leading to increasing risks of flooding, loss of wildlife habitat, and modifications in vegetation composition to the extent that the existence of some tree species (e.g., Schinopsis spp.) are endangered. While these problems are apparent to the trained observer and are being felt by the local people who suffer economically from their effects, there is surprisingly little solid information on the magnitude of the physical and socio-economic impacts. 15. Some observers (e.g., Redford et al, 1990) maintain that the arid environments of the tropics and semi-tropics, such as that found in the Chaco region, have the vegetation types most susceptible to alternation by man and the least understood. This is partially because the concentration of attention on the tropical rainforests has deflected attention from the more open vegetation formations of the semi-arid regions of South America. In fact, studies (Redford et. al., 1990) show that the rainforests do not hold a monopoly in terms of species richness. One study comparing the Chaco in Central Paraguay with the Manu National Park in Peru (a rainforest area) has shown that there were 30 species of large and medium size mammals in the Chaco region compared with 34 in the rainforest. Another study comparing the Gran Chaco (including Argentina, Paraguay and Bolivia) with the Venezuela lowlands east of the Andes, showed that the Chaco region has 53 species of medium and large mammals compared with the same number for the rainforest of Venezuela. The conclusion of these studies is that the Chaco region is as rich as tropical rainforests in terms of numbers of large mammalian species. One member of this study team was unable to find any area in the Argentina Chaco region that had not been modified by recent human activity and believes that the "degradation of the dry Argentina Chaco region is one of the greatest, yet least known, ecological catastrophes in South America" (Redford et. al., 1990). That article goes on to emphasize that we "do not yet know enough about the Chaco region to determine how or if sustainable development is possible", but that work there could "serve as an invaluable model for developing an understanding of ecological processes in arid regions." 16. Unlike the Patagonia region--which has the Center for Forest Investigation and Extension in Andean Patagonia (CIEFAP) and the National Commission for the

Argentina has started to define the role of the State in the forest sector in comprehensive legislation embodied in Law 13273 of 1948. Under this law, the National Forestry Administration of SAGyA, later to become the Argentine National Forestry Institute (IFONA --Law 20531 of 1973), was created. Law 13273 of 1948, encompassed only areas under Federal responsibility ("Territorios Nacionales"). At that time, the government adopted forestry management methods commonly used in European countries. It was in fact an Italian firm, later to become Argentinean, that started a pulp industry in the 1 920s. Europe further developed its influence in this sector after World War II, when refugees from many European countries, but most particularly foresters from Croatia, helped Argentine policy makers and its private sector to become aware of the sector's potential and the need for improving production and processing technologies. This coincided with the government's decision to expand its agriculture frontier and become increasingly self sufficient. A Forestry Directorate ("Direcci6n de Bosques") was created in most provinces by provincial governments. Under the influence of European immigrants, the forestry sector started to develop the necessary technology and to boost logging as well as commercial activities. 2. Despite such a promising start, the Provincial Forestry Directorates never had the human resources or the institutional capacity to really enforce Law 13273 of 1948. Provinces did not have skilled professionals to enforce federal or provincial legislation, even when it was effectively created. Instead, private entrepreneurs were left to continue their increasingly predatory use of the forests, and the prudence spelled out in the law was largely ignored. In other words, the provincial capacity to manage the forest sector was limited by their weak administrative ability to enforce existing laws, to formulate policies, or follow a structured course of action. These constraints contributed to the limited economic development of the forest sector over the years. This was further aggravated by the intense competition from crops and livestock, which have always enjoyed greater support in Argentina. 3. The creation of IFONA in 1973 reflected a renewed government interest in the forest sector for both natural resource protection and commercial development. However, as the above-listed constraints were largely ignored, or not addressed effectively, forest

B. The Role of the State and Development Policy 4. Both because of growing awareness of environmental threats and of business opportunities, the Government has recently moved from a de facto to a more conscious national forest policy. Important decisions made over the last several years illustrate the perceived need for change in the sector. However, the measures taken in this direction need to be considerably strengthened to yield the expected results in policy reform. Measures already taken include especially: (a) the creation (in 1992) of SRNyAH, directly reporting to the President of the Republic, and (b) the decision to create within SRNyAH the DRFN with responsibility for all aspects of native forests; and (c) the decision to create the Directorate for Forestry Production (DPF) within SAPyA, itself belonging to the Ministry of Economy. The emerging policy points towards a role for the private sector that would focus on production and marketing, and a stronger, but still lean, role for the State limited virtually to: (a) norm-making and enforcement, especially to protect natural resources; (b) managing directly a protected areas system; and (c) stimulating expansion and productivity growth in the private sector. Private sector stimulation would aim at increasing the area under plantations and enhancing considerably the level of technology and productivity in forest production. 6. Derived from the above, the implicit role of the State in the forestry sector would include: (a) adapting existing legislation and regulations to new requirements, (b) getting organized to ensure harmony and an adequate network of institutional relationships, both at the national and provincial levels; (c) disseminating relevant information and data; (d) generating relevant technology and making it available to the private sector directly or through extension activities; (e) directly intervening in areas in which there is insufficient interest or capacity in the private sector, but which generate substantial positive externalities; (f) managing directly national parks; and (g) promoting forestry-related training at all levels, including universities.

To achieve such objectives and to support the above-defined role of the State, substantially enhanced institutional capacity is required. Prior to addressing specific institutional capacity gaps (ICGs), a review of the sectoral institutional universe is given below as well as a description of the identified ICGs that became the basis for the design of the institutional development strategy and action plan included in the proposed project. The forest sector's institutional network is complex and unstable. This network is described below in some detail. 8. Federal Institutions. Six ministries are involved in the forestry sector in Argentina. After the dismantling of IFONA in 1991, its functions were redeployed and assigned to SAPyA for plantations and related commercial and processing activities, and the rest to a newly created SRNyAH within the Presidency of the Republic. DRFN within SRNyAH has responsibility for managing all aspects of native forests, while the National Parks Administration (APN), a semi-autonomous entity within SRNyAH, has the responsibility for the administration of national parks. SAPyA is also responsible for INTA, a semi- autonomous research and extension entity that includes a forestry research unit. 9. Other Ministries have minor but significant roles. The Ministry of Education and Culture is responsible for universities which have forestry training at the undergraduate and graduate levels. The Secretariat of Science and Technology, among others, has some responsibility for forestry research. Finally, the Secretariat of Industry and Commerce includes: (a) a National Directorate of Industries which has jurisdiction over forestry processing industries; and (b) a National Industrial Technology Institute, offering extension services to timber industries. 10. Other Forestry Entities at the National Level. In addition to the universities that carry forestry programs at the undergraduate and graduate levels, quite a few other entities have been created at the national level to address specific needs. Still others may have a substantial influence on decisions taken at the regional level, although they do not necessarily have an identity strictly related to the forestry sector. In addition to INTA's involvement with research and technology dissemination, there is: (a) INTI, which is involved in the modernization of industrial processes and reports to the Ministry of Economy; (b) CITEMA, a technical arm of INTI, which has responsibility for testing industrial processes and supporting private industry; (C) CICELPA, also a technical arm of INTI, which does work similar to CITEMA but only for the pulp industry; (d) CONICET, which reports to the Ministry of Education and Culture, and which is in charge of coordinating all research activities and financing those which are important for development in Argentina; (e) CONAQUE, which has responsibility for fostering the development and protection of the Quebracho tree; and (f) CNA, which has the same functions for the poplar tree. Institutions dealing with overall or regional coordination are: (a) CONADEPA, which reports to the President of the Republic on coordination of activities in the Patagonia region, where forestry resources are an important asset; and (b) Federal Investment Council (CFI), which coordinates actions of the provincial ministers of finance, including the municipal authorities of Buenos Aires, to ensure harmony and
 - 71 - Annex D coherence in development decisions affecting one or more provinces. In addition, the legislative effort dealing with forestry is coordinated by two ad hoc Forestry Commissions in the House of Representatives and the Senate, respectively. 11. Provincial Institutions. The 23 Argentinean provinces have different organizational arrangements for provincial government and administration. In the forestry sector, however, while the name of the administrative unit may change, the general institutional design is relatively simple. This reflects the organizational setting in all provinces. The focal point is a provincial Forestry Directorate, which is generally located at the third management layer of government, with responsibility for both native and planted forests. Each provincial Forestry Directorate is responsible for coordinating forestry-related activities of all other entities, including national, within its province. 12. The Private Sector. Since an Italian company began the pulp industry in Argentina in the 1 920s, the private sector has organized itself into powerful associations and guilds of all sorts. While the private sector has undoubtedly contributed to the development of the forestry sector, it has also been a major obstacle to the full implementation of Law 13273, because of its perception that this law was an impediment to quick and substantial profits. The most important private sector entities are: (a) AFOA, a grouping of all forestry producers; (b) AFCP, which includes the most powerful and wealthy part of the forestry-related private sector; (c) FAIMA, which includes about 2,000 timber companies; and (d) CIEF, a private research entity which conducts research on behalf of its associated members that supplements that carried out by the public sector. Finally, there are many NGOs dealing directly or indirectly with the forest sector and dedicated mostly to raising awareness about the need for protecting natural resources. 13. Overall Sectoral Coordination. To ensure a minimum of harmony and coherence in the forestry-related decision-making process at the national level, a National Forestry Commission (CNB) was created with representatives from the national and provincial governments, and from the private sector institutions listed above. The main role of CNB is to advise the authorities on policy and/or investment decisions, while at the same time ensuring that the private sector receives clear signals. D.  -72- Annex D Rules of the Game 15. Within this broad category of institutional capacity, four elements have been identified as limiting the sector's ability to develop, namely, governance, legislation, regulations, and culture. They are analyzed below. 16. Governance. The first element of governance is a clearly articulated and recognizable sectoral role of the State. Unfortunately, no such role is written anywhere, and can only be deduced from Government's decisions and/or informal declarations. Another important element of governance is the transparency and amount of participation allowed in the decision-making process; there is much room for improvement. 17. Poor policies have been the main constraint to the efficient growth of the forest sector in Argentina and to the protection of "green" environmental values. Most of the constraints stemmed from the lack of a clear policy environment outside the sector, including macroeconomic, financial, trade, transportation and labor policies. In recent years, as part of the macroeconomic liberalization and privatization programs of the Government, much has been achieved in eliminating policy distortions affecting the forestry sector. These measures will go a long way toward fostering efficient and sustainable growth in the sector and in removing incentives for depleting the "green" environment. 18. When private sector representatives are interviewed about changes they would like to see in the role of the State, they generally have precise ideas: (a) increased awareness on the pait of the Government of the sector's potential; (b) more public sector stimuli (direct promotion and fiscal incentives) to expand production; (c) more openness to the private sector to ensure its participation in the decision-making process, in particular on matters relating to international markets; and (d) research and extension programs more in line with private sector priorities and dictated by market conditions. 19. Legislation. Policy constraints to forestry growth and environmental protection still exist, however, mainly contained in sector-specific legislation. National forest policy in Argentina, as stated in Law 13273 of 1948, was very advanced for its time in that it struck a balance between conservation and commercial objectives. The law was less successful in its choice of policy instruments, because it favored "command and control" mechanisms rather than market-based mechanisms, which would have been more appropriate given the dominance of private forests in most of Argentina. Important policy constraints to forest development and environmental protection also remain at the provincial level. Provinces play a critical role in forest policy, but in most cases they have failed to implement the farsighted approach contained in law 13273 of 1948. Furthermore, provincial legislation tends to exacerbate the weaknesses of law 13273 by relying too much on "command and control" mechanisms that, for the most part, are misdirected and fail to achieve the underlying objectives. For example, some of these measures attenuate property rights by reducing private option values. This creates incentives against forests and in favor of competing uses, and introduces disincentives for conservation and forest development. Also, because provincial sectoral legislation varies
 - 73 - Annex D widely between regions, it creates inefficiencies in the location of the industry and fosters a provincial bureaucracy that, in many cases, does little more than collect special taxes to finance itself 20. Non-forest provincial policies also play an important role in distorting sector activities. Some provinces adopted special taxation schemes to promote value-added processing within provincial borders. Other provinces impose a tax on shipments of timber raw materials to outside the province, a practice that may even be unconstitutional. Transportation is still highly regulated at the provincial level, leading to the appearance of trucking associations that behave like oligopolies and increase the transportation costs of timber products. Finally, provincial legislation is particularly poor in the area of "green" environmental protection. Although most environmental values are national or global in scope, and it would not make sense for a province to take most initiatives in the absence of transfer payments from the federal government or the global community, there are still important local values, particularly for quality water supply and soil conservation, that are poorly protected. 21. Regulations. Furthermore, the related regulations are inadequate. For instance, in case of fire, there is no special mechanism to mobilize the population as provided for in the law. Also, there are no professionals to fight forest fires. This may result in the situation being worsened when only volunteer fire fighters, without training or guidance, are available. Regulations are also missing to help minimize risks. The existing fine system is obsolete and does not stimulate prudence. In the field of regulations related to commerce and industry, there is also a need for updating or creating new rules of the game, in particular to foster productivity increases and exports. Finally, the regulations related to watershed management are particularly weak. 22. Culture. Finally, it is readily acknowledged in Argentina that there is little or no "forestry culture" as compared with neighboring countries such as Chile. Awareness of both the sectoral development potential and the possibility of expanding the forestry capital stock, instead of just destroying it, is far from being sufficient. The development of such an awareness is seen by the private sector as an important role of the public sector. Another example of weak institutional capacity because of prevailing cultural patterns is given by native populations (Mapuches in particular) who used to invade forests of araucaria and araucana to eat their nutritious fruits, thus depleting wide areas of valuable trees. Interinstitutional Relationships 23. The network of interinstitutional relationships within the forestry sector is complex and unstable. In addition, most of the relationships are de facto or informal rather than thought through on the basis of the need for many entities to cooperate and interrelate to efficiently implement their work programs. Even when specific mechanisms exist such as the National Forestry Commission (CNB), it has no power whatsoever except to give advice. Experience has shown that this advice is rarely taken. At least this is the sentiment in the private sector when CNB is mentioned.
 - 74 - Annex D Internal Organization and Management at the Entity Level 24. Organization at the entity level within the forestry sector is at least as weak as it is at the interinstitutional level. In SRNyAH, weaknesses derive from its recent creation and the lack of overall experience as to how to get organized to respond to the specific needs of the country in protecting the environment and preserving natural resources. In the case of SRNyAH's DRFN, it is evidently located at too low a level hierarchically to have much influence or prestige. 25. This picture is further aggravated by gaps related to other elements of capacity also included in the broad category of "organization." These gaps are less specific to the forestry sector and more common to many public entities in Argentina. Management procedures and styles often seem antiquated. They do not include participatory mechanisms, except on very rare occasions. The entity-level interpretation of prevailing civil service rules is narrow and many entities' staff "work to rule", slowing down all processes and certainly activating only part of their skills. Only rarely are there adequate and updated manuals at the administrative and technical levels. Finally, as in many other sectors, entities are given responsibilities and work programs without the corresponding physical and financial resources (operating budgets) commensurate with the scope of their work. Facilities are not well maintained and run. Office equipment and technology generally do not cover the needs and tend to be obsolete as well. This situation has often been denounced by the private sector when explaining the low credibility level of the public sector. As a result, this element of capacity is far from adequate. On the contrary, any sector modernization effort aimed at achieving higher levels of performance and competitiveness in international markets, while simultaneously renewing the forestry sector's capital stock, both quantitatively and qualitatively, is going to be severely hampered by the above-described situation. Personnel Policies and Reward Systems 26. On this subject there is not much to say that would be specific to the forestry sector. However, this does not make the identified ICGs less severe when trying to achieve sectoral development objectives. It is well-documented that the civil service in Argentina needs to be reorganized in line with other government efforts to modernize the entire administrative machinery. Salary levels in the forestry sector are not at all competitive with the private sector. As a result, the private sector retains the best specialists, which is not necessarily a bad thing in itself However, as the role of the State in the sector becomes leaner, the need for a competent core of specialists within sector institutions is critical. Current personnel policies do not give any premium for the number of years specialists have spent in the same job and/or specialty. The system is seen as broadly unfair. Many of the existing higher- and mid-level specialists have a second job working in private activities that have nothing to do with the forestry sector. This is particularly serious in a sector in which a high level of competency is necessary to implement reforms such as the ones under the proposed project, including policy-making, definition of strategies to stimulate efficiently the private sector, and to enforce natural

Skills of Individuals in Both the Public and Private Sectors 27. Finally, from the viewpoint of the last institutional capacity category that has been reviewed while preparing the proposed project, namely, skills of people at all levels involved in interinstitutional relationships, wide capacity gaps exist, largely, but not exclusively, explained by the previously-described capacity gaps. Information obtained through informal interviews of both public sector officials and private sector entrepreneurs show that skills are missing at all levels, including in the private sector, to achieve the development tasks implied in the Government priority objectives. The majority of decision-makers are new to the sector. About 70 percent of the professionals and technicians, including those in the private sector which is supposed to get the best professionals as a result of better compensation packages, would need, at least, to update their skills. In the private sector, managers do not have the management or technical skills at the level required by an industry that wants to aggressively penetrate highly competitive international markets. Workers in the industry are generally unskilled, contributing to a well-known wastage of primary products. Finally, the population in general, including the groups visiting national parks or other protected areas, have neither a conservation culture nor awareness of what is expected from them as a contribution to natural resource protection. In other words, the global skill capital of the people, including within the sectoral institutional universe, is deficient. This probably will be a severe impediment to implementing the proposed sectoral development strategy if it is not addressed speedily and adequately. Conclusion 28. The Argentine Forest Sector has a weak institutional capacity because: (a) the sectoral role of the State and related development policy is only vaguely defined and is not sufficiently explicit or transparent; (b) the institutional environment is which the sector is developing is not conducive to the achievement of the highest development potential in terms of preserving natural resources and, at the same time, realizing the sector's full productive potential; and (c) the capacity of sectoral institutions is weak. Based on a comparison between existing institutional capacity thus described for the sector, and the one that is implied by the proposed project's development objectives, an institutional strengthening strategy is recommended that would help: (a) define a clearer role of the state and develop policy in effective consultation with the civil society; and (b) implement the proposed action program described below and included in the proposed project so as to eliminate, or at least mitigate, identified institutional capacity gaps for key capacity elements such as policy-making, legislation/regulations, interinstitutional and internal organization, personnel management, and skills.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Native Forests and Protected Areas Project for Argentina are to: a) help the Secretariat of Natural Resources and Human Environment prioritize its actions dealing with native forests; b) facilitate the development of an incentive and regulatory framework to encourage decision makers; both public and private, to more fully internalize within their decision making processes the full range of social costs and benefits associated with their decisions and actions affecting native forests; c) develop a plan for transforming the National Parks Administration into a world- class park management organization; and d) increase the environmentally sustainable level of tourism in four national parks. The project will have three components: a) generation and dissemination of research and information consisting of policy, legal and regulatory reform, a national inventory of native forests and establishment and operation of a related database; and applied research and studies to facilitate management and conservation of native forests and protected areas; b) protected areas comprised of the development of a plan for the modernization of the National Parks Administration and specific infrastructure development and management strengthening in four Patagonian Region parks; and c) project implementation.
